title: Morning After the Engagement - Family Breakfast

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Alcázar of Toledo awakens slowly, winter light filtering pale through the eastern windows of your private chambers. You slept deeply—more deeply than you have in months—and wake with a clarity that surprises you. The sapphire ring. The moonlit garden. "Yes. Yes, I will be your wife." It happened. It truly happened.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You rise and dress with the assistance of your body servants, choosing simple clothing—a dark woolen doublet, practical rather than ceremonial. There is much to be done today, but your mind keeps returning to those grey-green eyes, that sharp tongue, the way she placed the ring on her own finger rather than waiting for you to do it. "I will NOT be a quiet wife." No. You suspect she will not be.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: As you break your fast in your private solar—bread, cheese, olives, weak wine—a knock comes at the door. Don Álvaro enters, looking as though he has been awake for hours already. Papers are tucked under his arm.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: Your Majesty slept well, I trust?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: A hint of knowing in his voice. The entire Alcázar will have noticed you did not return from Lucia's apartments until well after midnight. Nothing improper occurred—the chaperones saw to that, and you would not dishonor your betrothed before the wedding—but tongues will wag regardless. Álvaro sets down his papers and meets your eyes.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: Congratulations are in order, I understand. The lady accepted?

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: The formal betrothal announcement must be made soon, Your Majesty. The Italian delegation, the court, the foreign ambassadors—they will all expect ceremony. But the lady's unusual request for a private meeting first means we have... flexibility. The question is timing.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He glances at his papers.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: Several matters require your attention today. But perhaps the most pressing is: when do you wish to see the Lady Lucia again? She is awake—her maid sent word she rose with the dawn and is taking breakfast in her apartments. Apparently she asked whether you are an early riser, or whether kings sleep until noon.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: A hint of amusement crosses Álvaro's weathered face.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: She also asked whether Castilian breakfasts are always so 'aggressively plain,' or whether this was a test of Italian resolve.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The autumn sun climbs higher over Toledo. Your betrothed is awake, your constable awaits your orders, and somewhere in this fortress your children are stirring.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Well, you know what they say: The work of a king is never done. Better get the marriage underway as soon as possible. How soon can we arrange?

encounters.recap: The morning after his successful proposal to Lucia d'Este, Juan reflects on the previous evening while breaking his fast. Don Álvaro arrives to discuss the formal betrothal announcement and reports that Lucia is already awake and making witty observations about Castilian customs. Juan decides to move forward with wedding preparations as quickly as possible.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: The formal betrothal announcement must be made soon, Your Majesty. The Italian delegation, the court, the foreign ambassadors—they will all expect ceremony. But the lady's unusual request for a private meeting first means we have... flexibility. The question is timing.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: She also asked whether Castilian breakfasts are always so 'aggressively plain,' or whether this was a test of Italian resolve.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Well, you know what they say: The work of a king is never done. Better get the marriage underway as soon as possible. How soon can we arrange?

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: As soon as possible? The Church requires the reading of banns on three successive Sundays before a valid marriage—that is canon law, and not even a king may dispense with it without papal intervention. Today is Friday, the eleventh of November. If we announce the betrothal publicly this Sunday and begin the banns immediately... First reading: Sunday, November 13th. Second: November 20th. Third: November 27th. The earliest canonically valid wedding date would be Monday, November 28th. Though a wedding on a Monday is unusual. Most would expect Saturday, December 3rd, or Sunday, December 4th.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: However, Your Majesty, there are... considerations beyond canon law. First: The Lady Lucia arrived only yesterday. A betrothal announcement tomorrow would set tongues wagging across Europe. Some will say the King of Castile is unseemly eager. Others will whisper that something improper occurred to necessitate such haste. I know nothing did. But gossip does not require truth, only opportunity.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: Second: The Italian delegation expects certain courtesies. A formal betrothal ceremony, exchange of gifts, time for the lady's household to prepare. Her uncle the Marquess sent six ladies-in-waiting and two confessors—they will want to feel their presence matters, not that they were rushed through like merchants at a toll gate.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: Third: Christmas is six weeks away. A wedding in early December would overshadow the season—or be overshadowed by it. Some would counsel waiting until after Epiphany, mid-January, when the court is refreshed and the roads more passable for those who wish to attend.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: My counsel? Announce the formal betrothal this Sunday, with appropriate ceremony. Let the banns be read. Wed in early December—perhaps Saturday the 3rd—before Christmas makes travel difficult. That gives three weeks for preparation, which is swift but not scandalous. Unless, of course, you have reasons for greater haste that I should know about?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Make it so Alvaro. Good suggestions. No, there is no need for more haste. Let's do things properly. Anything else for now?

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: December 3rd it shall be. I will coordinate with Archbishop Alonso and the Italian delegation. The betrothal ceremony this Sunday will require some arrangement—I suggest the Cathedral, followed by a formal reception here at the Alcázar. Nothing so grand as Fernando's baptism, but dignified.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: Other matters, Your Majesty. None urgent enough to spoil your breakfast, but several requiring your attention today or in coming days. First: Doña Beatriz sent word that Princess Catalina has been asking for you since she woke. Apparently she wishes to show you something she built with her wooden blocks. The lady Lucia has also been mentioned—Catalina keeps asking about 'the pretty lady' and whether she will visit again. The children will need to be told about the betrothal before the public announcement. How you wish to handle that is... delicate.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: Second: A courier arrived late last night from Commander Martín's Morocco expedition. The message is brief—they made landfall safely at Tétouan and have begun establishing contacts. No detailed intelligence yet, merely confirmation they arrived. The full report remains expected in the coming weeks.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: Third: Don Íñigo López de Mendoza requests an audience at your convenience. The Council of Great Houses has completed its first round of internal audits, and he wishes to present the findings personally. He seemed pleased, which suggests the news is good.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: The other matters can wait an hour. Have Don Íñigo come this afternoon. And tell Doña Beatriz I will see the children shortly—but first, I have a lady to attend upon.

encounters.recap: Juan and Álvaro plan the royal wedding to Lucia Visconti, deciding on a formal betrothal announcement this Sunday followed by the wedding on December 3rd. They discuss the canonical requirements, diplomatic considerations, and court protocol needed for a proper ceremony.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You set aside Álvaro's papers with a wave of your hand. The corridors of the Alcázar are quiet at this hour, servants moving softly about their morning duties. You pass through the gallery where autumn light falls in long golden rectangles across the stone floor, then climb the stairs to the guest apartments in the eastern wing—the finest rooms the fortress offers, traditionally reserved for visiting royalty.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Two of Lucia's Italian guards stand at the door, liveried in Ferrara's colors. They stiffen at your approach, clearly uncertain of protocol. You spare them the dilemma by stopping at a respectful distance and inclining your head.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Please inform the Lady Lucia that the King of Castile requests the honor of her company, if she is receiving visitors.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: One guard disappears inside. You hear a brief murmur of feminine voices—Italian, too quick to follow—and then laughter. Lucia's laughter, you think. Sharp and bright. The door opens wider. Lucia stands in the entrance herself, rather than sending a servant. She wears a morning gown of deep green wool, simple but beautifully cut, her dark hair loosely braided rather than elaborately styled. The sapphire ring glints on her finger—she has not removed it.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_d_este
exchanges.text: The King of Castile. Knocking at doors like a common suitor. Do they not teach kings to send servants with flowery messages and wait to be summoned? I was just telling my ladies that Castilian breakfasts appear to consist entirely of bread, olives, and stubbornness. They did not believe me. Come. Tell them I am not exaggerating. And explain to me why there is no frittata, no sweet pastries, no proper coffee— You do have coffee in Castile, yes?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Good morning ladies. I hear that we must amend our breakfast and include coffee?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Lucia's six Italian ladies-in-waiting rise hastily from their seats around a small table, curtsying in a flutter of silk and murmured greetings. The room smells of bread and honey—apparently someone found something sweet for the Ferrarese contingent—and a fire crackles in the hearth against the November chill. Lucia closes the door behind you, leaving her guards in the corridor.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_d_este
exchanges.text: Coffee. You say it as though you know what it is. This gives me hope. In Ferrara, we have it from the Venetian traders. Bitter, black, hot—it wakes the mind like nothing else. My uncle claims it is a Muslim invention and therefore suspect, but he drinks three cups every morning nonetheless.

exchanges.speaker: francesca_de_roberti
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, I am Donna Francesca de' Roberti. I served the Lady Lucia's mother, God rest her soul, and now attend the Lady herself. We have been... adapting to Castilian hospitality. The bread is excellent. The olives are... Abundant.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_d_este
exchanges.text: Ignore them. They are testing whether the King of Castile has a sense of humor or whether they must spend the rest of their lives being solemn and dull. You came yourself. This morning. Without sending a herald or a formal invitation or a procession of servants. I was not certain you would. Kings are busy. There are... matters of state, I am told.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Yes, I have received reports that a certain structure has been built requiring inspection by both myself and a mysterious 'Pretty lady'. But I also wanted to meet the ladies who have accompanied you from Italy. Donna Francesca, an honour to meet you. I understand that our Castilian diet seems crude to Italians and I look forward to discover how Italian cuisine can delight my entire court.

encounters.recap: Juan visits Lucia's chambers informally, meeting her Italian ladies-in-waiting. They discuss Castilian versus Italian breakfast customs, with playful banter about coffee and cuisine. The visit establishes a more personal tone between Juan and Lucia, away from formal court protocol.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_gonzaga
exchanges.text: Ignore them. They are testing whether the King of Castile has a sense of humor or whether they must spend the rest of their lives being solemn and dull.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_gonzaga
exchanges.text: You came yourself. This morning. Without sending a herald or a formal invitation or a procession of servants. I was not certain you would. Kings are busy. There are... matters of state, I am told.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Yes, I have recieved reports that a certain structure has been build requiring inspection by both myself and a mysterious 'Pretty lady'. But I also wanted to meet the ladies who have accompanied you from Italy. Donna Francesca, an honour to meet you. I understand that our Castillian diet seems crude to Italians and I look forward to discover how Italian cuisine can delight my entire court.

exchanges.speaker: francesca_strozzi
exchanges.text: Your Majesty is gracious. We Ferrarese pride ourselves on our kitchens, it is true. Perhaps too much. If Your Majesty permits, I would be honored to work with your household cooks. Not to replace Castilian traditions, but to... complement them. The Lady Lucia's mother always said that a harmonious table makes for a harmonious house.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Lucia watches this exchange with evident pleasure, then turns to introduce the others.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_gonzaga
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, my ladies. Donna Isabella Strozzi—she has the sharpest needle in Ferrara and will judge your entire court by the quality of their embroidery.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_gonzaga
exchanges.text: Donna Giulia Bentivoglio—her family are patrons of artists in Bologna, and she will expect paintings on every wall.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_gonzaga
exchanges.text: Donna Caterina de' Medici—a distant cousin of the Florentine branch, and our resident scholar. She reads Greek, which she reminds us of constantly.

exchanges.speaker: caterina_de_medici
exchanges.text: Only when relevant.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_gonzaga
exchanges.text: Donna Alessandra Gonzaga—her aunt married into Mantua, and she knows more gossip about every court in Italy than any spymaster.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_gonzaga
exchanges.text: And Donna Beatrice d'Este—my own cousin, sent by my uncle to ensure I do not do anything scandalous. She takes her duties very seriously.

exchanges.speaker: beatrice_d_este
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, I am honored—that is—the Lady Lucia exaggerates—

exchanges.speaker: lucia_gonzaga
exchanges.text: I never exaggerate. I merely emphasize.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_gonzaga
exchanges.text: Now. You mentioned a structure requiring inspection, and a 'pretty lady.' I confess I do not know what structure you mean—but I am very curious to meet this mysterious pretty lady of whom you speak. Is she a rival I should know about?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Mysterious indeed. I do not know, maybe if you come with me we can unravel this together.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Lucia takes your arm without hesitation, her hand light but confident on your sleeve. She glances back at her ladies.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_gonzaga
exchanges.text: Donna Francesca, you have command of the breakfast crisis. I expect solutions by the time I return.

encounters.recap: Juan meets Lucia's Italian ladies-in-waiting, each introduced with wit and personality. Donna Francesca offers to enhance the court's cuisine, and the group displays the sophisticated humor of the Italian Renaissance. Juan cryptically mentions a mysterious structure and 'pretty lady' requiring inspection, prompting Lucia to accompany him arm-in-arm to investigate.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_de_ferrara
exchanges.text: I never exaggerate. I merely emphasize. Now. You mentioned a structure requiring inspection, and a 'pretty lady.' I confess I do not know what structure you mean—but I am very curious to meet this mysterious pretty lady of whom you speak. Is she a rival I should know about?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Mysterious indeed. I do not know, maybe if you come with me we can unravel this together.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Lucia takes your arm without hesitation, her hand light but confident on your sleeve. She glances back at her ladies.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_de_ferrara
exchanges.text: Donna Francesca, you have command of the breakfast crisis. I expect solutions by the time I return.

exchanges.speaker: donna_francesca
exchanges.text: Yes, my lady. We shall storm the kitchens.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You walk together through the corridors of the Alcázar, and Lucia takes in everything—the tapestries, the stonework, the servants who stop and stare and then remember to bow. She says little, but you feel her attention like a living thing, cataloging, assessing.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_de_ferrara
exchanges.text: Your fortress is older than I expected. Ferrara is all new construction—my uncle tears down anything more than fifty years old and rebuilds it with more columns. This has... weight. History.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She pauses at a window overlooking the Tagus, the river silver-grey under the November sky.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_de_ferrara
exchanges.text: Isabel walked these halls.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Before you can respond, you reach the royal family's apartments. Doña Beatriz meets you at the door, and her eyes widen slightly at the sight of Lucia on your arm—but she is too well-trained to show more than a flicker of surprise.

exchanges.speaker: dona_beatriz
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. The princess has been waiting most eagerly.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She opens the door. The nursery is warm, a fire burning low, morning light streaming through the windows. And there in the center of the room sits Catalina—nineteen months old, dark-haired like her mother, serious-faced with concentration—surrounded by an ambitious construction of wooden blocks that appears to be either a castle or a very confused cathedral. She looks up at the sound of the door.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Papá!

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Her face splits into a radiant smile. Then her eyes move to the woman beside you, and she goes very still, studying Lucia with that peculiar intensity that small children possess.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Pretty lady. Come see. I builded it.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She points imperiously at her block structure. Lucia's grip on your arm tightens almost imperceptibly. You glance at her face and see something you did not expect—uncertainty. This sharp-tongued, quick-witted woman who bantered with you about empires in a moonlit garden looks, for just a moment, genuinely nervous. She takes a breath, releases your arm, and crosses the room to kneel beside your daughter, heedless of her fine green gown on the nursery floor.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_de_ferrara
exchanges.text: You builded this? It is very tall. What is it?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You lower yourself to the floor beside your daughter, crossing your legs as you have done a hundred times in this nursery. Catalina barely glances at you—her attention is fixed entirely on Lucia, this fascinating new creature who has knelt down to her level.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Is a castle. That's where Papá sleeps. That's where I sleep. Fernando sleeps... somewhere. He's little. Where do you sleep?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Lucia glances at you—a flash of those grey-green eyes, amused and slightly panicked—then turns back to Catalina with appropriate gravity.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_de_ferrara
exchanges.text: I sleep in a room with many ladies who talk too much. It is very noisy. Your castle looks much more peaceful.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Catalina considers this. Then, with the decisive air of a monarch granting a great favor, she selects a single wooden block from her pile and holds it out to Lucia.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: You can have a room. Next to Papá.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: From somewhere behind you, you hear Doña Beatriz make a small, strangled sound that might be a suppressed laugh. Lucia takes the block as though receiving a precious gift. Her hands, you notice, are not entirely steady.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_de_ferrara
exchanges.text: Thank you, Princess. I am honored.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Catalina nods, satisfied, and turns her attention to the critical work of integrating this new architectural element. She pats the floor beside her.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: You help. Papá is bad at building. He makes it fall down.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The single block tumbles, striking another, and a cascade of wooden destruction follows—Catalina's careful tower collapsing in a clattering avalanche across the nursery floor. For one frozen moment, Catalina stares at the ruins of her castle, her mouth a perfect O of shock. Then she rounds on you with the righteous fury that only a nineteen-month-old princess can muster.

encounters.recap: Juan brings Lucia de Ferrara to meet Princess Catalina in the nursery. Despite initial nervousness, Lucia charms the nineteen-month-old princess by engaging seriously with her block castle construction. Catalina, delighted with the 'pretty lady,' offers Lucia a block to build a room 'next to Papá,' creating an unexpectedly intimate moment before Juan playfully destroys part of the castle.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: From somewhere behind you, you hear Doña Beatriz make a small, strangled sound that might be a suppressed laugh. Lucia takes the block as though receiving a precious gift. Her hands, you notice, are not entirely steady.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Thank you, Princess. I am honored.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Catalina nods, satisfied, and turns her attention to the critical work of integrating this new architectural element. She pats the floor beside her.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: You help. Papá is bad at building. He makes it fall down.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The single block tumbles, striking another, and a cascade of wooden destruction follows—Catalina's careful tower collapsing in a clattering avalanche across the nursery floor. For one frozen moment, Catalina stares at the ruins of her castle, her mouth a perfect O of shock. Then she rounds on you with the righteous fury that only a nineteen-month-old princess can muster.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: PAPÁ! No! Bad! I builded that!

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She smacks your arm with her small hand—it has all the force of an angry sparrow—and her face crumples into theatrical outrage. She turns to Lucia, appealing to this new ally for justice.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: You see? He always does this.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Lucia is biting her lip, her shoulders shaking with barely contained laughter. She meets your eyes over Catalina's head, and something passes between you—a warmth, an ease, a shared recognition of the absurd and wonderful moment you find yourselves in. Then Lucia schools her expression into exaggerated solemnity and places a comforting hand on Catalina's shoulder.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: I see. This is very serious. What should we do with him?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Catalina considers the question with the weight it deserves, her brow furrowed in concentration. She looks at you, then at Lucia, then at the scattered blocks.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: He has to fix it. And no knocking down.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You set to work under Catalina's exacting supervision, picking up blocks and presenting each one for her approval before placing it.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: This one?

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: No, Papá. That one goes there.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: And so it goes—block by block, correction by correction. Catalina stands with her hands on her hips like a master mason overseeing incompetent apprentices, occasionally sighing at your inadequacy. When you place a block at a slight angle, she fixes it herself with an air of long-suffering patience. Lucia watches from her place on the floor, her chin resting on her hand. At some point during the reconstruction, Catalina apparently decided that the 'pretty lady' had earned supervisory privileges as well, and began directing comments to both of you.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: There, see? Now it's the big one. The big one, Papá.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The structure rises again—not quite the same as before, but close. Catalina adds the final block herself, a small wooden rectangle that she places at the very top with ceremonial gravity.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Done. Is better now. The pretty lady has a room. And no one knocks it down.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: This last is delivered with a stern look directly at you. From the corner, you hear the soft fussing sounds of Fernando stirring in his cradle—ten weeks old now, beginning to notice the world around him. Doña Beatriz moves quietly to check on him. Lucia rises from the floor, brushing off her gown, and extends a hand to help Catalina up—an instinctive gesture, natural and unthinking. Catalina takes it without hesitation.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Your castle is very fine, Princess. Perhaps tomorrow you will show me how to build one myself?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Have you been keeping watch over your brother Catalina?

encounters.recap: Juan playfully knocks down Catalina's block castle, earning her theatrical outrage. Under her strict supervision, he rebuilds it with Lucia's help, creating a warm family moment that deepens the bond between all three as they approach baby Fernando's crib together.

exchanges.text: From the corner, you hear the soft fussing sounds of Fernando stirring in his cradle—ten weeks old now, beginning to notice the world around him. Doña Beatriz moves quietly to check on him.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Lucia rises from the floor, brushing off her gown, and extends a hand to help Catalina up—an instinctive gesture, natural and unthinking. Catalina takes it without hesitation.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Your castle is very fine, Princess. Perhaps tomorrow you will show me how to build one myself?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Have you been keeping watch over your brother Catalina?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Catalina giggles as you lift her, wrapping her arms around your neck. She immediately adopts your exaggerated stealth, pressing one finger to her lips in imitation of what you've clearly done before.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Shhhhh.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You creep together toward the cradle, your footsteps theatrical and slow. Catalina cranes her neck to peer over the edge as you approach, her small body tense with the importance of the mission. Fernando lies in his cradle, ten weeks old and growing quickly. He has kicked off part of his swaddling and is making the soft gurgling sounds of a baby discovering his own hands. His eyes—dark like his mother's, like Catalina's—track vaguely toward the movement above him.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: I watch him. He's very little. He doesn't do anything yet. But Doña Beatriz says he will get bigger and then he can play. He cries a lot.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Fernando, as if to demonstrate, makes a small squawking sound and waves one tiny fist in the air. Catalina watches this with great interest. Behind you, you hear the soft rustle of fabric—Lucia has followed, standing a few paces back. When you glance at her, she is watching the three of you with an expression you cannot quite read. Something tender and guarded all at once, as though she is witnessing something precious and fragile that she is not yet certain she is allowed to touch.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: This pretty lady is called Lucia. She is staying with us from now on. Would you like to give her a hug like you do with papa?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Catalina studies Lucia with the grave deliberation of a princess evaluating a new addition to her court. She looks at Lucia's face, then at you, then back at Lucia—processing this information with visible care.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Lucia. Loo-thee-ah. Okay.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She leans out from your arms toward Lucia, reaching with the absolute trust of a child who has never been dropped—arms extended, fingers grasping, wholly committed to the transfer. Lucia hesitates for just a heartbeat. You see her take a breath. Then she steps forward and receives Catalina into her arms, settling the toddler against her hip with a naturalness that surprises you both. Catalina wraps her arms around Lucia's neck and squeezes with the fierce, uncomplicated grip of a nineteen-month-old.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: You smell nice. Like flowers.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Thank you, Princess. You smell nice too. Like... blocks. And breakfast.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Catalina pulls back just enough to look at Lucia's face, apparently conducting a final inspection. Then she nods, satisfied, and pats Lucia's cheek with one small hand.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: You can stay.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Dona Beatriz, has Catalina had breakfast yet?

exchanges.speaker: dona_beatriz
exchanges.text: Not yet, Your Majesty. The princess was too busy with her construction to be tempted by food. I had thought to try again after— the inspection was complete.

encounters.recap: Juan introduces Lucia to his children in the nursery. Catalina accepts her with characteristic directness, giving her a hug and granting permission for her to stay. The tender moment shows Lucia beginning to find her place in the royal family as she holds Catalina and observes baby Fernando.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Lucia's eyes meet yours over Catalina's head. They are bright—too bright—and her voice is not entirely steady when she speaks.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Thank you, Princess. You smell nice too. Like... blocks. And breakfast.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Catalina pulls back just enough to look at Lucia's face, apparently conducting a final inspection. Then she nods, satisfied, and pats Lucia's cheek with one small hand.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: You can stay.

exchanges.speaker: dona_beatriz
exchanges.text: Not yet, Your Majesty. The princess was too busy with her construction to be tempted by food. I had thought to try again after the inspection was complete.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: I'm hungry.

exchanges.speaker: dona_beatriz
exchanges.text: There is bread and honey waiting, Your Majesty, and some of the soft cheese the princess favors. I can have it brought here, or if Your Majesty wishes, the princess could take her breakfast elsewhere, if you have further need of the nursery.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: How many? Are they nice? Do they have... things?

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Six? That's... that's a lot. Yes. We go now. To see the things.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: It seems I have my orders. Donna Francesca will be delighted. She has been trying to find someone who appreciates Italian sweets since we crossed the Alps.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The three of you make your way back through the corridors of the Alcázar—you walking beside Lucia, Catalina still perched on her hip and providing commentary on everything you pass. By the time you reach the eastern wing, Catalina has informed Lucia about the location of the kitchens, the best window for watching horses in the courtyard, and the terrible injustice of not being allowed to touch Papá's sword.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Hello! We're HERE! We have come to see the THINGS!

exchanges.speaker: donna_francesca
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. My lady. And this must be the Princess Catalina. We have heard much about you.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The moment Lucia sets Catalina down, the princess stands frozen for a moment—overwhelmed by the reality of six ladies, all of them turning to look at her with various expressions of delight and curiosity. Then Catalina's natural confidence reasserts itself. She walks directly to Donna Isabella Strozzi and points at the embroidery hoop in her lap.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: What's that?

exchanges.speaker: donna_isabella_strozzi
exchanges.text: This is needlework, Princess. I am making a picture with thread. See?

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: It's a bird.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She makes her way around the room like a small dignitary conducting inspections. Donna Giulia Bentivoglio receives a long stare and the observation that her necklace is 'very sparkly.' Donna Caterina—the scholar—is asked if she can read, and when she confirms that she can, Catalina nods sagely and says, 'Doña Beatriz reads to me. About horses.' Young Donna Beatrice d'Este receives the declaration 'You look like Lucia,' before Catalina moves on.

exchanges.speaker: donna_francesca
exchanges.text: I understand you have come to see the things. And to have breakfast. Is this true? Then you have come to the right place. This is called a crostata. It is made with almonds and honey. Would you like to try?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I think this is something very special Catalina. Not something we can eat every time, but for now we can.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Catalina accepts the pastry with both hands, holding it like a sacred object. She takes a bite. Her face transforms. Eyes widening, cheeks bulging, an expression of pure wonder spreading across her small features.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Papá, it's so good. Is there... more?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Is there a crostata for papa as well?

exchanges.speaker: donna_francesca
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, we had hoped you might ask. The kitchens were... receptive to collaboration. Once we explained that Italian pastries require Italian techniques, they were most accommodating. The honey is Castilian, of course. Excellent quality.

exchanges.speaker: donna_caterina
exchanges.text: Coffee, Your Majesty. We brought our own supply from Ferrara. There is enough to share, if you are curious.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Now, it is a proper morning.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: You can have one more crostata Catalina. But you have to choose carefully. Each one is slightly different you see? Which one will you pick?

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: That one is... brown. What's that one? A sun. The sun one. But I can try the brown one tomorrow?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I do not know if there will be crostatas tomorrow Catalina. Crostatas are something very special. But maybe next time when we visit the six ladies, they will have very special good bread.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Okay. Next time, special bread. The sun.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: She is... She is extraordinary, Juan. You have done well with her. Isabel must have been remarkable.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The study is warm, a fire crackling in the hearth against the November chill. Catalina has settled onto a cushion near the fireplace with a wooden horse—someone, probably Doña Beatriz working through the Alcázar's efficient servant network, has ensured toys were waiting.

encounters.recap: Juan brings Catalina to meet Lucia's Italian ladies in their apartments for breakfast. The princess charms the ladies while discovering Italian pastries, particularly crostatas made with almonds and apricots. The morning creates a warm domestic scene as Catalina bonds with Lucia and the Italian women show their delight with the young princess, leading to genuine affection between the groups.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The study is warm, a fire crackling in the hearth against the November chill. Catalina has settled onto a cushion near the fireplace with a wooden horse—someone, probably Doña Beatriz working through the Alcázar's efficient servant network, has ensured toys were waiting. She makes the horse trot across the cushion, murmuring quiet narratives to herself. Lucia takes a seat near the window, slightly apart from your desk but clearly present. She has brought a small book from her apartments—devotional, by the look of it—but her eyes drift toward you and Álvaro more often than toward the pages.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. The more pressing matter is this: a letter arrived this morning from Commander Martín in Morocco. More substantial than the brief landing confirmation we received previously. I have not opened it, but the messenger indicated it contains his initial assessment of conditions in Tétouan and prospects for the mission.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Álvaro hands you the sealed packet. You break the wax—Commander Martín's seal, a simple cross over a crescent moon, the symbol he chose after his baptism. The letter is substantial: several pages in Martín's careful hand, written in Castilian but with occasional Arabic terms where no translation suffices.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Commander Martín reports establishing presence in Tangier and Tétouan, with all twenty-three delegation members alive and well. In Tangier, they present as merchants, aided by freed prisoners' testimony of your honorable treatment. The city is fragmented with competing factions. In Tétouan, rebuilt by al-Andalus refugees, the local qadi shows cautious interest in trade relations. Salé proved impossible—corsairs control it and threatened to kill 'apostates.' The Marinid Sultan is weak, Morocco fragmenting into independent local powers. Martín advises Morocco cannot be conquered like Granada, but relationships can be built with future leaders. He requests trade goods and formal introduction for Fernando's scholarly work.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: This is good news. We are establishing a foothold and are beginning to understand Morocco. But a conquest proves to be much more difficult than anticipated. We should write them back and let them continue their work as is, grant them the trade goods requested. Ask them to begin exploring if we could put one faction in power in exchange for the city to become a Castilian vassal. Religious customs would be respected and trade would increase. The city would be ruled by a christian with strong ties to the region or Islam. Who understands the traditions. Do not approach any faction with an offer yet, just gather information for now.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_d_este
exchanges.text: May I see the letter?

encounters.recap: Commander Martín's detailed report from Morocco reveals moderate success: presence established in Tangier and Tétouan, basic intelligence network functioning, and cautious local reception aided by freed prisoners' testimony. However, Morocco proves too fragmented for conquest, with the Marinid Sultan weak and local powers acting independently. Juan approves continued operations and requests intelligence on potential vassal arrangements with local factions.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: We should write them back and let the continue their work as is, grant them the trade goods requested. Ask them to begin exploring if we could put one faction in power in exchange for the city to become a Castillian vassal. Religious customs would be respected and trade would increase. The city would be ruled by a christian with strong ties to the region or Islam. Who understands the traditions. Do not approach any faction with an offer yet, just gather information for now. I turn to Lucia. Anything to add?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Lucia rises from her seat by the window and moves closer, her expression thoughtful. She has clearly been following every word.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_d_este
exchanges.text: May I see the letter?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She takes it from your hand and scans the pages quickly—you notice her eyes moving with the practiced speed of someone accustomed to reading correspondence. When she finishes, she sets it down on your desk.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_d_este
exchanges.text: Your Commander Martín writes well. He understands that information is worth more than territory. This is the key passage. A dying realm with a child sultan and competing regents. Factions that hate each other more than they hate you.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_d_este
exchanges.text: Your instinct is sound—find a faction to support. But I would add a caution. Do not let them know you are choosing between factions. Let each faction believe they are the only one you are considering. The moment they learn you are shopping for allies, your value to any of them diminishes. They will compete to offer you less, not more.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_d_este
exchanges.text: In Ferrara, my uncle plays the Italian powers against each other this way. Venice believes they are the only one you are considering. Also—the qadi in Tétouan. Ahmad ibn Yusuf. He waits to see which way the wind blows, your commander says. Such men are useful, but they are not loyal. They serve whoever appears strongest. If you elevate him, you must remain stronger than any alternative, or he will turn the moment a better offer appears.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_d_este
exchanges.text: But these are merely observations. I do not know Morocco. Your commander does.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: For now, we just observe and do not approach any faction yet. We need more information. Send these instructions to Martin. Make sure he recieves the trade goods. What else?

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: I will draft the response for your seal and arrange for the trade goods—steel, worked leather, and a selection of Granada silks. We can send them by way of a Genoese merchant vessel out of Málaga; it will attract less attention than a Castilian ship.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: That leaves Don Íñigo López de Mendoza this afternoon—the Council of Great Houses audit results. He has been waiting patiently. From what I understand, the news is favorable. The Council has conducted audits on three member houses and collected some fifteen thousand maravedís in underpayments. More importantly, the other great houses are watching. If this model proves effective, we may see additional families petition to join.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He glances at Catalina, who has abandoned her wooden horse and is now attempting to stack the loose papers on the corner of your desk into a tower.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: Shall I schedule Don Íñigo for after the midday meal? That would give Your Majesty time to... attend to other matters.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: From her chair, Lucia suppresses a smile.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Schedule him for lunch today, this is fine.

encounters.recap: Juan discusses Morocco policy with Lucia and Álvaro, deciding to gather more intelligence on factions before making any approaches. They arrange for trade goods to be sent to Commander Martín via Genoese merchants. Álvaro reports that Don Íñigo López de Mendoza is ready to present the Council of Great Houses audit results, which appear favorable with 15,000 maravedís collected and growing interest from other noble houses.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The small dining chamber adjacent to your study has been prepared for an informal working lunch. Nothing so grand as a banquet—bread, roasted fowl, cheese, olives, and wine sufficient for conversation without ceremony. Catalina has been returned to Doña Beatriz's care, though not without protest. Lucia remains, positioned to observe without intruding.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Álvaro escorts Don Íñigo López de Mendoza into the chamber. The head of House Mendoza is a man in his middle fifties, his dark hair silvered at the temples, his bearing that of a scholar as much as a lord.

exchanges.speaker: inigo_lopez_de_mendoza
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. I thank you for receiving me. And I see congratulations are in order. Word travels quickly in Toledo. The lady Lucia d'Este, I presume?

exchanges.speaker: inigo_lopez_de_mendoza
exchanges.text: My lady. House Mendoza welcomes you to Castile. I hope you will find our kingdom worthy of your gifts.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_deste
exchanges.text: Don Íñigo. Your reputation precedes you. I am told you are both a lord and a poet—a combination I thought existed only in old romances.

exchanges.speaker: inigo_lopez_de_mendoza
exchanges.text: The romance is somewhat less glamorous in practice, my lady. Mostly it involves arguing with stewards about grain prices and then writing melancholy verses about the futility of arguing with stewards.

exchanges.speaker: inigo_lopez_de_mendoza
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, I come bearing news of the Council of Great Houses. We have completed our first year of operation, and I believe the results merit your attention.

exchanges.speaker: inigo_lopez_de_mendoza
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, I will be direct. The Council has grown, though not as swiftly as I had hoped. When we began last November, House Mendoza stood alone—proposing a concept that many found... unusual. Great families policing themselves? Voluntary audits? Consultation without demanding concessions? My peers suspected a trap.

exchanges.speaker: inigo_lopez_de_mendoza
exchanges.text: In the first months, we had only the three founding houses—Mendoza, and two families closely allied with us by marriage. The turn came in spring, after Your Majesty's return from Rome and Basel. Three more houses approached us between April and August. House Enríquez, House Guzmán, and House Manrique. That brings us to six families.

exchanges.speaker: inigo_lopez_de_mendoza
exchanges.text: Collections for the full year stand at approximately forty-three thousand maravedís. The audits have uncovered modest underpayments, errors in accounting, a few cases of deliberate evasion quietly corrected. No scandals. No public humiliations. The system works as intended.

exchanges.speaker: inigo_lopez_de_mendoza
exchanges.text: We have also begun something I did not anticipate. Consultation. When House Guzmán faced a dispute with a lesser family over grazing rights, they brought it to the Council rather than pursuing it through royal courts or private warfare. We mediated. The matter was resolved in three days rather than three years.

exchanges.speaker: inigo_lopez_de_mendoza
exchanges.text: The foundation is solid, Your Majesty. The institution is proving itself. But it has not yet achieved the momentum that would make membership expected rather than optional. We are at a delicate stage—past the point of failure, not yet at the point of inevitability.

exchanges.speaker: inigo_lopez_de_mendoza
exchanges.text: There are several paths, Your Majesty. First: The Velasco Question. If House Velasco joins, it transforms the Council overnight. Second: A Visible Royal Consultation on some matter of policy where noble input is appropriate. Third: Handle a more visible dispute to demonstrate the Council's value beyond tax compliance.

exchanges.speaker: inigo_lopez_de_mendoza
exchanges.text: Fourth: Charter and Formalization. A royal charter would give us permanence. Fifth: The Danger to Avoid. The Council must never become—or appear to become—a mechanism for royal control of the nobility.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I think that a letter signed by me would be appropriate for now. Alvaro, can we draft a letter addressed to the council thanking them for the great initiative and cooperation so far, bring honour to the houses who have joined. I will ask them on input on the structure on Granada titles and obligations and future lands to be conquered. In addition, I will instruct my marshals to first approach the council in case of a perceived issue before approaching the noble directly, should the noble be a part of the council.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: A wise approach, Your Majesty. The letter accomplishes several things at once—public recognition, genuine consultation, and a practical benefit to membership. I will draft it for your review this evening.

exchanges.speaker: inigo_lopez_de_mendoza
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, the matter of the Crown Marshals is... significant. If the Marshal approaches the Council first, the dynamic transforms entirely. The Council investigates its own member. Peers examine peers. This will bring House Velasco in. I am nearly certain of it.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_deste
exchanges.text: And the consultation on Granada titles—this is clever as well. You ask for advice on a matter that directly concerns noble interests. They will argue amongst themselves about the structure, which tells you what they want. In Ferrara, my uncle calls this 'letting them write the map of their own desires.'

exchanges.speaker: inigo_lopez_de_mendoza
exchanges.text: The lady has a political mind.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_deste
exchanges.text: The lady grew up watching her uncle play Venice against Milan against Florence. One learns, or one becomes a pawn.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The conversation turns to lighter matters over the roasted fowl and wine. Don Íñigo speaks of his children—three sons and two daughters, his youngest daughter insisting on reading everything in his library, including texts he considers unsuitable for a girl of fifteen.

roll.outcome: Solid Growth. Three to four new houses joined, bringing total membership to six or seven great families. Collections of 40,000-50,000 maravedís. The Council meets regularly and has begun informal consultations.

encounters.recap: Don Íñigo reports on the Council of Great Houses' first year progress during a working lunch. The Council has grown to six families with 43,000 maravedís collected and has begun mediating disputes. Juan proposes writing a formal letter of recognition, consulting the Council on Granada titles, and having Crown Marshals approach the Council first for member issues—moves that particularly excite Don Íñigo as likely to attract House Velasco.

exchanges.speaker: inigo_lopez_de_mendoza
exchanges.text: The lady has a political mind.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_visconti
exchanges.text: The lady grew up watching her uncle play Venice against Milan against Florence. One learns, or one becomes a pawn.

exchanges.speaker: inigo_lopez_de_mendoza
exchanges.text: Is there anything specific you wish me to convey to the Council before the letter arrives? Any... preparation of the ground, as it were?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The conversation turns to lighter matters over the roasted fowl and wine. Don Íñigo speaks of his children—three sons and two daughters, the eldest son recently married to a lady of House Enríquez, which explains some of that family's willingness to join the Council.

exchanges.speaker: inigo_lopez_de_mendoza
exchanges.text: My youngest daughter has her mother's stubbornness and my unfortunate tendency toward verse. She insists on reading everything in my library, including texts I consider unsuitable for a girl of fifteen. Last week I found her annotating Ovid. Annotating. With corrections.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_visconti
exchanges.text: I think I should like to meet this daughter.

exchanges.speaker: inigo_lopez_de_mendoza
exchanges.text: God help us all if you do, my lady. She needs no encouragement.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You speak of Catalina's wooden horse named Horse, of Fernando's growing strength, of the small moments that make up a father's days between matters of state. Don Íñigo listens with the attention of a man who remembers his own children at that age, offering occasional observations—how quickly they grow, how the years that seem endless in the moment become precious in memory. Álvaro, for his part, remains largely silent, though you catch him smiling once or twice at the domesticity of it all.

exchanges.speaker: inigo_lopez_de_mendoza
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. My lady. This has been a most productive conversation. I confess I arrived uncertain whether the Council's progress would meet your expectations. I leave... encouraged.

exchanges.speaker: inigo_lopez_de_mendoza
exchanges.text: House Mendoza has served the crown for generations, Your Majesty. But I think perhaps we have never served a king who understood so well that strength and partnership are not opposites.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Lucia, would you like to go on a little trip with me? If we are to travel together a lot, I would like to see how you travel and how best to accommodate you. When we go to Constantinople, I assume your ladies will come as well?

exchanges.speaker: lucia_visconti
exchanges.text: A trip? Before we are even formally betrothed? What will the court say? Yes, my ladies would accompany me to Constantinople. Donna Francesca would insist—she has managed my household since I was fourteen and would sooner walk into the sea than let me sail to the edge of Christendom without her.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_visconti
exchanges.text: But you are not asking about Constantinople, not really. You want to know what manner of traveler I am. Whether I will slow your progress with complaints about rough roads and inadequate lodgings. Whether I require a wagon full of comforts or can ride beside you.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_visconti
exchanges.text: I grew up in Ferrara, Juan. A small court, always watching larger powers circle. My uncle taught me that survival requires movement—the ability to leave quickly if necessary, to travel light, to adapt. I can ride. I can sleep in conditions that would make Donna Francesca weep. I can eat camp food without complaint, though I reserve the right to observe that it is terrible.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Just a short trip for a few hours. I want to take Catalina as well. She best get used to riding on horses. I want to see how well she is suited for travel as well.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_visconti
exchanges.text: A few hours, with a child of nineteen months? You are testing all of us, I see. Very well. I accept your challenge.

encounters.recap: After concluding the Council discussion with Don Íñigo López de Mendoza over lunch, Juan proposes a short riding trip to test how well Lucia and young Catalina travel together, planning for future journeys including the eventual trip to Constantinople.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_visconti
exchanges.text: Catalina—does she ride with you, or does she have her own pony? At nineteen months, I assume she is not yet in the saddle alone, but children vary. My youngest cousin was on a pony at two and terrorizing the stable master by three.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She waits for your answer, already calculating, already adapting—the mind of a woman who approaches even a simple afternoon ride as a problem to be solved efficiently. Álvaro, still gathering his papers, watches this exchange with the expression of a man who is revising his estimates. Whatever he expected of the Italian bride, this practical directness was perhaps not it.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: She will ride with me for now.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You find Catalina in the nursery with Doña Beatriz, engaged in what appears to be a very serious conversation with her wooden horse about the merits of various types of hay. Fernando sleeps peacefully in his cradle, oblivious to his sister's agricultural discourse.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Papá! You came back!

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You carry Catalina through the corridors of the Alcázar and out into the afternoon air. November in Toledo is crisp but not bitter—the sky a pale blue, the sun providing warmth enough for a short ride. Catalina chatters the entire way, pointing out everything she sees.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The royal stables are warm with the smell of horses and hay. Grooms snap to attention at your arrival, bowing low. Catalina goes suddenly quiet, her eyes wide as saucers. She has seen horses before, of course—from windows, from the courtyard at a distance. But here, in the stables themselves, the animals loom enormous.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Papá, they are big. That one, what is her name?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: That is my horse, Hidalgo.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Hidalgo is a destrier of Andalusian blood—grey coat shimmering almost silver in the stable light, black mane and tail, the powerful chest and strong legs of a warhorse bred for generations. You stand before him, letting his warm breath wash over you both. Slowly, carefully, he extends his great head toward Catalina. She shrinks back against your chest for a moment. Then, with the unpredictable courage of children, she reaches out one small hand.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: He's soft. He likes me, Papá. He likes me!

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The groom moves quickly to assist, holding Hidalgo's bridle steady as you lift Catalina onto the saddle. She grips the pommel with both hands, her knuckles white, suddenly aware of how high she is from the ground. Then you swing up behind her, settling into the saddle, your arms coming around her to take the reins. The tension drains from her small body.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Good Hidalgo. Good horse. We are going to ride now. Where are we going, Papá? Can we go fast?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The sound of boots on cobblestones interrupts her. Lucia emerges from the stable entrance, transformed. Gone is the fine wool morning gown. She wears now a riding habit of deep green—practical, well-cut, clearly made for actual riding rather than merely looking elegant on horseback.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_visconti
exchanges.text: I see the princess has claimed the best seat. Wise girl. Always ride with the king if you can. Which horse have you prepared for me?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Lucia moves into the stables with purpose, not rushing but not hesitating either. She stops before a black mare with a white blaze on her forehead—tall, perhaps fifteen hands, with an intelligent eye and a restless energy.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_visconti
exchanges.text: This one. What is her name?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Tormenta, my lady. She is... spirited.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_visconti
exchanges.text: Spirited. Is that a polite way of saying she has thrown riders? Saddle Tormenta.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You guide Hidalgo out of the stables and into the courtyard, where the afternoon sun casts long shadows across the cobblestones. Around the courtyard you go, letting Catalina find her balance. By the fifth circuit, she is confident enough to release one hand and pat Hidalgo's neck.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: I'm riding! Good horse. Good Hidalgo. You walk very nice.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You hear hoofbeats behind you—sharper, more energetic. Lucia emerges from the stables on Tormenta. The black mare is indeed spirited, tossing her head and dancing sideways as Lucia guides her into the courtyard. But Lucia sits her well—back straight, hands firm but not harsh on the reins.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_visconti
exchanges.text: She is spirited. But she listens. She just needed to know I meant it.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: You look like a queen.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: A small escort assembles quickly—six mounted guards under the command of Sergeant Tomás who has ridden with you through worse than a peaceful afternoon in the Castilian countryside. They form up around you with practiced efficiency, three ahead and three behind, close enough for protection but far enough to allow conversation.

encounters.recap: Juan takes nineteen-month-old Catalina for her first horse riding lesson at the royal stables. Despite initial fear, Catalina bonds with Juan's warhorse Hidalgo. Lucia demonstrates her riding skills by choosing and successfully handling the spirited black mare Tormenta. The family prepares to ride out into the countryside with an escort, marking Catalina's first proper equestrian experience.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: She is spirited, but she listens. She just needed to know I meant it.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Tormenta snorts and stamps, eyeing Hidalgo with the wariness of a mare assessing a much larger stallion. Hidalgo, for his part, ignores her entirely—the unflappable dignity of a veteran. Catalina stares at Lucia on the black horse, her mouth open.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: You look like a queen.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: A small escort assembles quickly—six mounted guards under the command of Sergeant Tomás who has ridden with you through worse than a peaceful afternoon in the Castilian countryside. You guide Hidalgo through the gates of the Alcázar and down through Toledo's winding streets. Citizens stop and stare—their king, riding with a child before him and a striking dark-haired woman at his side.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Catalina, we are going to ride out into the country. Do you see the river down there? The river is called the Tagus. We will cross the bridge and ride along the other side, where there are farms and fields and olive groves.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Olives? I like olives.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You reach the Puente de Alcántara, ancient Roman stonework that has spanned the Tagus for over a thousand years. Catalina watches the water flowing beneath with fascination.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: The water goes fast, Papá.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: It does. The Tagus flows all the way to the sea, far to the west. To Portugal, where your grandmother lives.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Abuela? The water visits Abuela?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: In a manner of speaking. We will ride for perhaps an hour, and then rest and have something to eat. And then we will ride back. The whole time, you will be with Papá, safe on Hidalgo. And the Lady Lucia will ride with us, so she can see the land that will be her home.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: I will show her the olives.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: There is another matter we must still discuss, love. You have six ladies, but there are also the four Portuguese doñas still taking care of Catalina and Fernando. I have offered them a home in my court to give Catalina something to remember her mother by. If all four Portuguese ladies want to come along to Constantinople as well, we may not have space for everyone. And how do you feel about their presence anyway?

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: You are asking me several questions at once. Let me answer them separately. First—how do I feel about their presence. They are not a threat to me. They served Isabel. They love Isabel's children. This does not diminish me. I would be a fool to resent women who have cared for Catalina and Fernando when I was not yet here to do so. In truth, I am grateful for them. Catalina knows their faces, their voices, their ways. She has already lost her mother. To strip away everyone familiar in favor of Italian strangers would be cruel. Children need continuity, Juan. Even when everything else changes.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Second—Constantinople. You are right that space will be limited, even on a royal flagship. Ten ladies-in-waiting, plus servants, plus your retinue, plus guards... It becomes a floating court, not a diplomatic mission. My suggestion: let the ladies choose. Some of my Italians may prefer to remain in Toledo. Perhaps two or three of mine come, and one or two of the Portuguese, and the others remain to manage the household and care for Fernando. Fernando should not come to Constantinople. He is too young, the voyage too dangerous. Which means someone must stay with him whom we trust absolutely. Doña Beatriz, perhaps—she has been with Isabel's household the longest.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Third—you called me 'love.' I noticed. I am choosing to notice. You may continue.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Have you seen a ship Catalina? Do you know what a ship is?

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Ship. Ship is... boat? Big boat? Doña Beatriz has a picture. In her book. A big boat with... the things. That catch the wind.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Sails. They are called sails, little one.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Sails. Ships have sails, Hidalgo. Why, Papá? Are we going on a ship? Where does the ship go? Does the ship go to Abuela? On the water that visits her?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: In many days and nights, we will go on Hidalgo and travel to the sea. There is a ship with sails. And we will go on the ship and then travel on the sea for many days. And you know what? Ships have names. And do you know what the name is of the ship we will be travelling on? The ship is called 'Princess Catalina'.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Catalina goes very still. She stares up at you, her small mouth falling open. For a moment she seems unable to process what you have said—the words too large, too strange, too wonderful to fit inside her nineteen-month-old understanding of the world.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: The ship... the ship is called me?

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: It is true, little one. Your Papá named his great ship after you.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Catalina looks back at you. Her lower lip trembles—not with sadness, but with the overwhelming weight of a feeling she does not yet have words for. Then her face breaks into the most radiant smile you have ever seen on her, a smile that seems to illuminate her entire being.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: My ship. I have a ship. I love you, Papá. I love you so much. Can Lucia come on my ship? And Hidalgo? Can Hidalgo come?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I dont know if Lucia will come. Maybe you should ask her.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Lucia, will you come on my ship? Please?

encounters.recap: Juan takes Catalina and Lucia on a countryside ride outside Toledo to discuss travel arrangements. They plan the household for the Constantinople voyage, with some Portuguese and Italian ladies staying to care for Fernando while others accompany the journey. Juan reveals that his flagship is named 'Princess Catalina,' delighting his daughter, who then formally invites Lucia to join them on the voyage.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: These are for you. I picked them. From the tree.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: These are beautiful. You picked these yourself? From the tree?

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: From the tree. They live there. I didn't know.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She settles onto the blanket between you and Lucia, reaching immediately for the bread and cheese. Her legs stick out in front of her, still slightly unsteady from the ride, and she chatters as she eats—a stream of observations about the horses, the hawk she saw, the olive trees, the funny way Tormenta tossed her head.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You watch her, and you see it clearly now—what the Portuguese ladies have surely noticed, what Doña Beatriz must report in her quiet way. Catalina is not merely recovering from the loss of her mother. She is thriving. She learned Lucia's name after hearing it once and has not forgotten it. She remembers the promise of crostatas from this morning and connected it to the concept of "special bread" for future negotiations. When Hidalgo frightened her, she mastered her fear within minutes. When presented with six strange Italian women, she conducted her own inspection and rendered judgment. She accepted Lucia into her world with remarkable speed—not indiscriminate trust, but genuine openness.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She is curious about everything. Why do olives grow on trees? Where does the water go? What is the ship's name? The questions tumble out faster than you can answer them, each answer spawning three more questions. And beneath the curiosity, there is warmth. She offered Lucia a hug this morning without prompting—a gift freely given. She wanted Lucia to come on "her" ship. She picked olives not to eat herself, but to give.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She laughs easily, recovers quickly from small upsets, and seems to genuinely enjoy meeting new people rather than fearing them. The trauma of losing Isabel at ten months old has not broken her. Perhaps she was too young to fully understand; perhaps she was surrounded by enough love that the wound healed cleanly; perhaps she simply has a resilient spirit.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: She is... She is sunshine, Juan. How did you make such a child?

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: I'm not sunshine. I'm Catalina.

roll.outcome: Warm and Quick. Catalina combines genuine intelligence with a sunny, affectionate disposition. She is curious, eager to learn, quick to laugh, and forms bonds easily. She handled her mother's loss with remarkable resilience—sad at times, but not broken. She adapts well to new situations. A genuinely delightful child who brings joy to those around her. Robust health.

encounters.recap: A developmental assessment reveals that 19-month-old Princess Catalina has thrived despite losing her mother at ten months. She displays remarkable intelligence, curiosity, and emotional warmth, easily forming bonds and adapting to new situations while maintaining a sunny disposition and robust health.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Cathedral of Toledo fills before dawn. Word has spread through the city, and citizens crowd the plaza outside, hoping for a glimpse of their king and his Italian bride. Inside, the great families of Castile assemble in their finest—velvets and silks, gold chains and family jewels, the accumulated splendor of a kingdom celebrating peace after generations of war.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Don Íñigo López de Mendoza sits with his family in a place of honor. The Enríquez contingent occupies another section. You note, with quiet satisfaction, that Don Pedro Fernández de Velasco has come from Burgos—the first time the Count of Haro has attended a royal ceremony since your coronation. He catches your eye and inclines his head, his weathered face unreadable.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The altar blazes with candles. Archbishop Alonso de Toledo waits in his ceremonial vestments, ancient and solemn. You stand before the assembled court in cloth-of-gold, your father's sword at your side. The True Cross fragment and Santiago's bone rest on the altar—the relics you carried to Rome and back, now witnessing another sacred moment.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: A murmur ripples through the cathedral. The doors have opened. Lucia enters on the arm of Don Íñigo, who has been granted the honor of escorting her in the absence of her uncle. She wears a gown of deep blue velvet embroidered with silver stars—the colors of Ferrara, but also of the Virgin. A thin circlet of gold sits on her dark hair. She carries no flowers, no ornament but the sapphire ring already on her finger.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She walks the length of the cathedral with her head high, her grey-green eyes fixed on you. The Archbishop raises his hands.

exchanges.speaker: archbishop_alonso_de_toledo
exchanges.text: We are gathered in the sight of God and these witnesses to join this man and this woman in the sacred promise of betrothal...

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The ceremony is brief and ancient. The Archbishop asks the questions required by canon law.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I do so promise.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_of_ferrara
exchanges.text: I do so promise.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You take the ring from her finger—the ring you gave her in the moonlit garden—and place it there again, publicly this time, before God and Castile.

exchanges.speaker: archbishop_alonso_de_toledo
exchanges.text: Before these witnesses, I pronounce you betrothed, bound by sacred promise to wed according to the rites of Holy Mother Church. What God has begun, let no man put asunder.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The cathedral erupts. 'Vivat! Vivat Rey Juan! Vivat Lady Lucia!' Lucia's hand trembles slightly in yours. When you look at her face, her eyes are bright with unshed tears—but she is smiling.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_of_ferrara
exchanges.text: Trapped.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The great hall of the Alcázar has been transformed for the reception. Musicians play in the gallery. Wine flows freely. Tables groan with food—Castilian and Italian dishes side by side, a culinary alliance to match the matrimonial one. Catalina, in a gown of pale yellow that matches the autumn chrysanthemums decorating the hall, sits in a place of honor with Doña Beatriz hovering nearby.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Papá, crostatas?

exchanges.speaker: lucia_of_ferrara
exchanges.text: As promised, little one. You earned it.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The evening stretches on. There is dancing—you lead Lucia through the steps of a pavane, her hand light in yours, her movements graceful despite unfamiliarity with Castilian forms. And through it all, Lucia stays at your side, her ring catching the candlelight, her sharp tongue softened for once into simple happiness.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_of_ferrara
exchanges.text: Three weeks. Three weeks until I am truly yours.

encounters.recap: King Juan II and Lucia of Ferrara are formally betrothed in a grand ceremony at Toledo Cathedral before the assembled nobility of Castile. The Archbishop performs the ancient ritual, rings are exchanged, and the cathedral erupts in celebration. A festive reception follows at the Alcázar with dancing, music, and both Castilian and Italian cuisine, marking the successful alliance between the kingdoms.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The days settle into a rhythm. Mornings find you in the stables with Catalina, lifting her onto Hidalgo's back before mounting behind her. She has grown bolder with each ride—no longer gripping the pommel with white-knuckled terror, but sitting straighter, sometimes releasing one hand to pat Hidalgo's neck or point at something that catches her eye.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Faster, Papá?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Not yet, little one.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The stable master is a grizzled man named Pedro Carrillo, who has served the royal stables for thirty years and trained horses for your father before you. He watches your daily rides with Catalina from the courtyard, arms folded, professional eye assessing. When you pose your question, he strokes his grey beard thoughtfully.

exchanges.speaker: pedro_carrillo
exchanges.text: For sitting a horse with an adult, as Your Majesty does now? She is already learning—balance, rhythm, comfort with the animal. This is good. The earlier they lose their fear, the better. For a pony of her own, with a lead rope held by a groom? Three years old, Your Majesty. Some say four, but I have seen children of three take to it well, if they have the temperament. The princess... She has no fear. That is half the battle. For riding independently, without a lead? Five or six, depending on the child. Short distances, gentle ponies, always supervised. By eight or nine, if she takes to it, she could ride properly—hunts, hawking, travel.

exchanges.speaker: pedro_carrillo
exchanges.text: There is a mare in the stables, Your Majesty. Andalusian, but small—fourteen hands only. Gentle disposition, good with noise and confusion. She was meant for Queen Isabel, before... She has been idle too long. In a year or so, she might suit the princess for her first pony. With your permission, I could begin training her for a child's temperament.

exchanges.speaker: pedro_carrillo
exchanges.text: It shall be done, Your Majesty. I will begin working with the mare immediately—accustoming her to sudden movements, high voices, the unpredictability of small children. For the pony, I will send inquiries to the breeders in Córdoba and Jerez. What we want is a Castilian pony, twelve hands or less—sturdy, calm, forgiving of mistakes. They are not rare, but a good one, one worthy of a princess... That takes time to find. I will have candidates for Your Majesty's inspection by spring, well before the princess turns three.

exchanges.speaker: pedro_carrillo
exchanges.text: If I may speak plainly, Your Majesty? The princess has a gift. Some children freeze on horseback—their bodies fight the animal's movement. Others relax too much and flop about like sacks of grain. But she... She listens to the horse. Feels him. It cannot be taught, only encouraged. Her mother was the same way, Your Majesty. Queen Isabel rode like she was born to it. God rest her soul.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
