exchanges.text: Your Majesty's generosity honors the Orders. Santiago accepts this charge. We will learn to fight on the water as we learned to fight on land—through discipline, faith, and perseverance.

exchanges.speaker: pedro_gonzalez_de_padilla
exchanges.text: Calatrava will not be found wanting. If pirates threaten Castilian waters, we will hunt them. Though I reserve the right to complain about seasickness.

exchanges.speaker: juan_de_zuniga
exchanges.text: Alcántara is honored, Your Majesty. I will write to Master Sotomayor in Constantinople immediately. He will be... pleased.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: I will prepare documents for the fortress distribution and port assignments, Your Majesty. And draft letters to King João regarding Portuguese knowledge of the African coast—Prince Henrique in particular has been exploring southward for years. His expertise would be invaluable. Regarding Salé—the question of how Tangier and Tétouan would react to a punitive raid is delicate. Commander Martín's reports suggest the cities operate largely independently; there is little love lost between them. Salé's corsairs prey on everyone's shipping, including vessels that might otherwise trade with Tangier. It is possible the other cities would quietly welcome Salé being... chastened. But we should confirm this before acting. A raid that unites Morocco against us would be counterproductive. Shall I instruct Commander Martín to make discreet inquiries? Assess whether Tangier and Tétouan might turn a blind eye—or even provide intelligence—if Castile moved against Salé?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Yes, write Martin to seek this out. Alvaro, lets make a list of all the forts and lets divide them fairly among the orders.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Lucia catches your wink and raises an eyebrow almost imperceptibly—a silent acknowledgment that she is watching, learning, filing away every detail of how you manage men and institutions.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: Very well, Your Majesty. Let me compile the full list and propose a division. Santiago receives the central region with 8 major fortresses including the Alcazaba of Granada, Alhambra garrison complex, Loja, Alhama, Montefrío, Íllora, Moclín, and Santa Fe. Calatrava takes the eastern region with 8 fortresses including the Alcazaba of Almería, Alcazaba of Guadix, Baza, Vera, Mojácar, Purchena, Fiñana, and Huéscar. Alcántara receives the western region with 7 fortresses including the Alcazaba of Málaga as garrison, Ronda, Marbella fortress, Estepona, Setenil, Archidona, and Antequera. For ports: Santiago gets Almuñécar, Calatrava gets Almería, and Alcántara gets Marbella. All three Orders granted mooring rights at Málaga, which remains crown property as the primary Mediterranean trading hub. Does this division seem equitable, Your Majesty? The Masters may wish to negotiate specific positions amongst themselves, but this provides a framework.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Do the masters agree with this division?

exchanges.speaker: luis_de_guzman
exchanges.text: Santiago is well served by this arrangement. The central region—Granada itself, the heart of what we conquered—carries symbolic weight, and the fortresses form a coherent defensive line. Almuñécar as our port is acceptable. It is modest, but sufficient to begin learning the naval craft. Santiago agrees.

exchanges.speaker: pedro_gonzalez_de_padilla
exchanges.text: Calatrava holds the route to Almería and the eastern approaches. Good. Guadix and Baza guard the mountain passes. Almería itself is a fine port—deep water, defensible. I might ask whether Vera and Mojácar could be exchanged for something closer to Guadix, to tighten our lines. But these are minor matters. Calatrava agrees in principle. We can negotiate details amongst ourselves.

exchanges.speaker: juan_de_zuniga
exchanges.text: Alcántara receives one fewer major fortress than the other Orders. But Marbella and Ronda are strong positions, and the western coast faces Morocco directly. If the future lies across the Strait... Master Sotomayor will need to formally ratify any agreement, but speaking for the Order in his absence—Alcántara agrees. The western region suits our ambitions.

exchanges.speaker: luis_de_guzman
exchanges.text: There is one matter we should settle amongst ourselves, with Your Majesty's permission. The secondary fortifications and watchtowers along the borders of our regions—where Santiago's territory meets Alcántara's, for instance. We will need to agree on precise boundaries to avoid... disputes. I propose the three Orders meet separately to draw these lines, then present the agreement to Your Majesty for approval. This keeps minor territorial squabbles out of the royal council chamber.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I would like to have the grant ready and signed by me before you all leave. I will take the grant to Alcantara with me to Constantinople, but the others I can sign now. I want each order to have one document stating what new titles, forts and areas they now also command. Why dont the masters work out any details together and present the result to me so I can sign it. Would that suit the masters? The queen and I have other matters to attend to in the mean time.

exchanges.speaker: luis_de_guzman
exchanges.text: Your Majesty honors us with such trust. We shall retire and work out the details amongst ourselves—the boundary lines, the secondary fortifications, the watchtower assignments. I expect we can have a proposal ready by tomorrow morning. These are complex matters, but the framework Your Majesty has provided is clear.

encounters.recap: Juan II assigns the three military orders their portions of conquered Granada, granting each order coastal fortresses and ports to develop naval capabilities against Barbary pirates. Santiago receives the central region including Granada itself, Calatrava takes the eastern region with Almería, and Alcántara gets the western region facing Morocco with Marbella. All orders are granted mooring rights at Málaga. The masters agree to work out detailed boundaries amongst themselves and present formal agreements for royal signature.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You find Catalina in the nursery, presiding over an elaborate construction of wooden blocks, cushions, and what appears to be an entire collection of wooden horses arranged in military formation. Doña Beatriz sits nearby, mending a small garment while keeping one watchful eye on her charge. Fernando lies in his cradle, awake for once, his dark eyes tracking the movement of a cloth bird that Doña Beatriz has hung above him.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Papá! Lucia-mama! I was very good. I watched Fernando. He did nothing. He just looked at the bird. For ages. Is it time for horses now? You promised. Lucia-mama promised Tormenta. You said after the boring.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Fernando blinks up at you, his dark eyes—so like Isabel's, so like Catalina's—focusing slowly on your face. At three months old, he is beginning to take notice of the world around him, though his understanding of it remains a mystery known only to infants and God. He makes a small sound, somewhere between a gurgle and a coo, his tiny fists waving aimlessly in the air. One hand finds your finger and grips it with surprising strength—the instinctive grasp of a baby who has discovered something solid in a confusing world.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: I ride with Lucia-mama to the stable. And then I ride with Papá on Hidalgo. And then I ride with Lucia-mama on Tormenta on the way back. That way it is fair.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: The princess drives a hard bargain. Very well. I accept these terms.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Hidalgo surges beneath you, his powerful muscles coiling and releasing as he thunders across the open field. Catalina shrieks with delight, pressed safely against your chest, her small hands gripping the pommel with white-knuckled excitement.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: FAST! Papá, we're going SO FAST!

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Behind you, you hear Tormenta's hooves—Lucia giving chase, the black mare's competitive spirit ignited once more. The sound grows closer, and Catalina twists in your arms to look back.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: The King flees! What will the chronicles say?

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Go faster, Papá! Go faster, Lucia-mama!

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The two horses run neck and neck across the stubbled field, grey and black, king and queen, with a princess laughing between them as the sun sinks toward the western hills and the first stars begin to prick the darkening sky.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: That was... so good. Can we do it every day?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You bring Hidalgo alongside Tormenta, and Lucia reaches out to receive the drowsy princess. The transfer is gentle—Catalina's small arms releasing your neck and finding Lucia's, her head settling against the woman's chest as naturally as if she had always belonged there.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: I have you, little one.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Tormenta is warm. And Lucia-mama smells nice...

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: She trusts me. Completely. Without reservation. I have done nothing to earn this, Juan. I have been here mere weeks. And yet she...

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The walls of Toledo rise before you, torches already lit along the battlements, the city preparing for night. Somewhere within, Fernando sleeps in his cradle. Somewhere, Álvaro drafts letters and the Military Order Masters negotiate boundaries. Somewhere, the machinery of a kingdom turns. But here, on this road, there is only the quiet clop of hooves, the weight of a sleeping child, and two people riding home together.

encounters.recap: Juan takes Lucia and Catalina to the stables for the promised riding expedition. They visit Fernando in the nursery first, then head to the countryside where Juan and Catalina gallop on Hidalgo while Lucia gives chase on Tormenta. Catalina falls asleep in Lucia's arms on the ride home, demonstrating the deep trust and bond that has formed between stepmother and daughter in just a few weeks.
